name: Typescript
definition: Typescript is a superset of JavaScript that adds optional static typing. It can catch many common bugs during compile-time and provides better tooling and developer experience for large-scale projects.

name: Static Typing
definition: TypeScript allows you to define types for your variables, function parameters, and function return values, catching type-related errors during compile-time rather than runtime.

name: Interfaces
definition: Interfaces define the shape of an object, ensuring that objects have the required set of properties with the correct types.

name: Classes
definition: While JavaScript has classes since ES6, TypeScript enhances classes with static types, access modifiers, and other features.

name: Generics
definition: Generics allow you to write reusable and type-safe functions and classes by providing a way to make components work with any type rather than a single one.

name: Type Inference
definition: TypeScript can automatically detect and assign the type of a variable based on its initial value, reducing the need to explicitly annotate the type.

name: Enums
definition: Enums allow you to define a set of named constants. They can be numeric or string-based.

name: Namespaces
definition: Namespaces provide a way to group related code in a block. They were more common before ES6 modules, but they can still be useful in certain situations.

name: Type Guards
definition: Type guards are runtime checks that narrow the type within a block of code, making it easier to work with union types.

name: Decorators
definition: Decorators are special functions that can be used to modify or annotate classes, properties, methods, and parameters. They're used heavily in frameworks like Angular.

name: Ambient Declarations
definition: Ambient declarations are a way to tell the TypeScript compiler about the types of external code, such as libraries included from a CDN. They're often defined in '.d.ts' files.
